Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Grey-to-White Matter Ratio in Predicting Neurological Outcomes in Heat Stroke

Trial_Design.evidence: Conducted as a multicentre retrospective study

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients over 18 years diagnosed with heat stroke who underwent cranial CT.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the prognostic utility of the grey-to-white matter ratio (GWR) in predicting neurological outcomes in heat stroke patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was neurological status at discharge, assessed by CPC scores.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Due to the retrospective nature, randomisation and blinding were not applicable.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the retrospective nature, randomisation and blinding were not applicable.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 128 heat stroke patients were enrolled from five hospitals in China between January 2020 and November 2023.

Number_Analysed.evidence: All GWRs were significantly lower in the poor outcome group compared to the good outcome group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The GWR basal ganglia demonstrated the highest sensitivity (80.95%) and specificity (90.77%) for predicting poor outcomes.
